attributes.title: Phase 1
attributes.description: In phase 1, participants will be asked to watch a video of the victim's testimony. We will then record their "stories" of what they think occurred during the alleged rape.

q1.value: The effect of testimony order on jurors' story construction in cases of alleged rape - Phase 1

q2.value: Harrison Lee, Blake McKimmie, Barbara Masser, Jason M Tangen

q3.value:
The aim of the first two studies in this program of research was to test how mock jurors evaluated the testimony of a rape victim when it was presented chronologically or with the rape event first. Participants’ evaluations (i.e., whether the events described in the testimony depicted rape or consensual sex) were measured every second as they watched the video of the victim testifying. Specifically, participants moved a slider between two scale endpoints (1 = consensual sex, 100 = rape) when responding to this measure. Using this design, we investigated how participants evaluated specific events described in this testimony (i.e., the rape event), by recording the position of the slider during certain parts of the video. After participants watched the video, they were also asked how likely it was that the defendant was guilty of committing rape. Contrary to our predictions, across both studies, participants in both testimony conditions did not differ in their likelihood of finding the defendant guilty of rape. However, participants who watched the testimony where the rape event was presented first were more likely to evaluate this event as rape compared to those who watched the testimony presented in a chronological order.

The findings of the two studies described above suggest that presenting the rape event first to participants may have allowed them to evaluate the key evidence (i.e., the rape event) as accurately depicting rape. However, it remains unclear whether ordering the testimony in this way had any effect on participants’ perceptions of the overall case (i.e., their perceptions of defendant guilt). Another method of assessing participants’ perceptions of the overall case may be to ask them what they think occurred during the events described by the victim (i.e., construct a story). According to the Story Model (Pennington & Hastie, 1993), jurors organise the information presented to them at trial into a story of what they think occurred during the alleged crime. To construct this story, jurors will often rely on their schemas related to the crime as well as the evidence presented during the trial. As such, the type of story a juror constructs will often indicate whether they perceive the events alleged as depicting rape or consensual sex. 

Furthermore, the story a juror constructs goes on to play an important role during deliberation. According to the Story Sampling Model (Devine, 2012), one-way jurors deliberate is by sharing their stories with the other members of the jury. As a group, the jury will then decide which story they think best accounts for what occurred in the alleged crime. A story that is coherent, and consistent with jurors’ schemas related to the crime, as well as the evidence presented during the trial, will likely be accepted by the jury as the best story (Pennington & Hastie, 1993). The jury will then attempt to match the accepted story to the verdict that fits best (Devine, 2012). As such, during the deliberation in a rape trial, jurors who listen to a coherent story that matches their expectations of what occurs in a typical rape may be more likely to believe that the defendant is guilty. In contrast, jurors who listen to a coherent story that matches their expectations of what occurs in typical consensual sex may be more likely to believe that the defendant is not guilty. It is therefore critical to investigate whether changing the order in which events are presented in the victim’s testimony influences the type of stories (i.e., rape stories vs consensual sex stories, coherent vs incoherent stories) mock jurors construct, from the perspective of other mock jurors. 

The aim of the current study is to investigate whether changing the order in which the victim’s testimony is presented causes mock jurors to construct different types of stories of what occurred during the alleged rape, from the perspective of different mock jurors. To investigate this, we will conduct the study in two phases. In phase 1, participants will construct stories of what they think occurred during the alleged rape after they watch a testimony where the rape event is presented first, or the events are presented in a chronological order. Pennington and Hastie (1986) assessed the type of stories mock jurors created by having them “think aloud” – that is, say out loud exactly what they were thinking about the case after watching a video of the evidence presented at trial. As such, in phase 1 of the current study, we plan to ask participants to think aloud as they say what they think happened on the night of the alleged rape. We will record participants’ responses as they complete this task. These recordings will then be rated by participants in phase 2.

q4.value: The main purpose of phase 1 is to collect responses from participants which will be used as stimuli in phase 2. As such, no hypotheses will be tested in phase 1 of the study.

q5.value: Experiment - A researcher randomly assigns treatments to study subjects, this includes field or lab experiments. This is also known as an intervention experiment and includes randomized controlled trials.

value: For studies that involve human subjects, they will not know the treatment group to which they have been assigned.
Personnel who interact directly with the study subjects (either human or non-human subjects) will not be aware of the assigned treatments. (Commonly known as “double blind”)

question.value: The overall project (i.e., phase 1 + phase 2) will incorporate a fully nested design with one fixed factor (testimony order) and one random factor (stimuli). In phase 1, participants will be randomly allocated to one of two conditions to form the between-subjects manipulation of testimony order (chronological testimony, rape event first testimony). The key measured variable in this phase is participants’ responses to the verbal narrative task (i.e., saying out loud what they think occurred during the alleged rape). The recordings of participants’ responses to this task will form the random factor (stimuli) in the overall mixed effects model. Other measured variables in phase 1 include the guilt likelihood measure and the choice of verdict measure.

q9.value: Participants will be randomly allocated to watch either the chronological testimony or the rape event first testimony. During the experiment, participants will be assigned either the number “2” or the number “1”. If participants are assigned the number “2”, they will be assigned to watch the rape-first version of the testimony. If they are assigned the number “1”, they will be assigned to watch the chronological testimony. This randomisation occurs in the programming script of the study and so participants are not aware of this allocation process.

q10.value: Registration prior to creation of data

question.value: Participants will be students recruited from the first year research participation scheme at the University of Queensland. Participants will be excluded from participating in the study if they are under 18 years of age. This exclusion criterion is necessary as the minimum age to serve on a jury in Australia is 18 years old. On the first year research participation scheme website, students will see advertisements for a number of studies that they can participant in for course credit. If a student is eligible to participate, they can book in a time to complete the study which will be conducted in a laboratory owned by one of the researchers.

q13.value: We will recruit 39 participants from the first year research participation scheme.

q14.value: An a priori power analysis was conducted using software specifically designed to estimate sample sizes for mixed effects models (Judd et al., 2016). This software was used to estimate the sample size required to power phase 2 of the current study at 0.8 power to detect a significant effect of d = 0.59 at an alpha value of 0.05. This effect size was used in the analysis as we consider it to be the smallest meaningful effect size of interest (after considering the effect sizes observed in the two studies described above). This power analysis revealed that a sample size of 385 participants with 35 targets (i.e., the recordings collected from participants in phase 1) will be needed to detect significant effects in phase 2 of the proposed study. Given these results, we aim to collect data from 39 participants in phase 1. This target sample size will ensure that we have sufficient power in phase 2 should any participants opt not to complete measures or withdraw from the study.

q15.value: We will recruit participants until we reach our target sample size.

question.value: We will manipulate testimony order by varying the order in which the victim describes the events in her testimony. In the chronological testimony, the victim will describe the events as they happened on the night of the alleged rape (i.e., the events which occurred before the alleged rape followed by the rape event). In the rape-first version of the testimony, the victim will first describe the rape event followed by the events which occurred before the rape (please see attached "videos" for links to these videos on YouTube).

Verbal narratives will be operationalised by participants’ verbal responses to the following instructions: “Now, please imagine that you are sitting with the other members of the jury and discussing whether the defendant, Neil Fox, is guilty or not guilty of committing rape. During this discussion, the other members of the jury ask you what you think happened on the night Janine was allegedly raped by Neil. Please say out loud what you think happened on the night of the alleged rape. In your own words, please say how you think the events described by Janine in her testimony unfolded and why they happened.” Participants will then be instructed to press a “record” button when they are ready to start telling their story. Further, participants will be told to press a “stop recording” button when they have finished telling their story. 

Choice of verdict will be assessed using a single item: “Now please decide whether the defendant, Neil Fox, is guilty or not guilty of rape.” Participants may answer this question by selecting either “guilty” or “not guilty”. 

Guilt likelihood will be assessed using a single item: “How likely is it that Neil Fox (the defendant) is guilty of committing rape” with participants responding on a 1 (not at all) to 7 (very) scale, with higher scores denoting greater guilt.

The manipulation of testimony order will be assessed by one item: “At what point during the video did you hear Janine discuss the defendant forcing her down and penetrating her?” with participants responding on a 1 (very early in the video) to 7 (very late in the video) scale.
An independent samples t-test will be run to test the differences between each level of testimony order on the manipulation check measure.

q20.value: Participants' recorded verbal narratives will be edited using voice-altering software so that their voices are unrecognisable. This transformation will ensure that participants' identities will remain protected when their recordings are listened to by participants in phase 2.

q22.value: No awareness checks will be performed. Participants will be excluded from the analyses if they do not respond to the verbal narrative task. Participants will also be excluded from the final sample if they do not respond to the dependent or manipulation check measures.

q23.value: Any missing data will be treated under the guidelines of Pigott (2001), where participants will be excluded from the final sample if they are missing at least 50% of their data.

q24.value: A two-tailed independent groups t-test may be run to test the differences between each level of testimony order on the guilt likelihood measure. A chi-square test may also be run to test the differences between each level of testimony order on the choice of verdict measure.

Pennington, N., & Hastie, R. (1986). Evidence evaluation in complex decision making. Journal of Personality and Social Psychology, 51(2), 242–258. https://doi.org/10.1037/0022-3514.51.2.242

Devine, D. J. (2012). Jury Decision Making: The State of the Science. New York University Press.

attributes.title: Peer Pressure, Gender, and Organizational Involvement

q1.value: Peer Pressure, Gender, and Organizational Involvement

q3.value:
The purpose of our study is to see if there is a relationship between peer pressure,
gender, and organizational involvement for college aged students. This relationship will be measured through the use of convenience sampling by having participants conduct a survey that will ask about their involvement in extracurricular activities and their age, gender, and race. We will also measure peer pressure through the peer pressure scale.

q4.value: There will be a positive correlation between peer pressure on college students affiliated with extracurricular activities and organizations.  Also, there will be a positive correlation between peer pressure and male involvement in extracurricular activities more than female.

value: No blinding is involved in this study.

question.value:
We plan to recruit college age students. (desired demographic to answer the research
question) We will need an adequate number of boys and girls in order to measure gender.

q10.value: Registration prior to creation of data

question.value:
At least 40 undergraduates from Clemson University will participate in this study.  
Participants will be recruited through email, social media, or word of mouth.  
All those involved will be 18 years or older.
The study is online through Qualtrics.

q14.value:
We used the software program G*Power 3.1 to conduct a power analysis. 

Our goal was to obtain .80 power to detect a medium effect size of .15 at the standard .05 alpha error probability.  To do this, we’d need at least 68 participants.

q15.value:
We will plan to collect data for 3 weeks (from 3/5/20 - 3/25/20). 
We will stop data collection at the end of that 3 week period.

question.value: None

DV: Peer Pressure
Q-IV: Gender & Organization Involvement

We will use a correlation test to determine if there is relationship between Extracurricular Activities and Feelings of Peer Pressure.  Next, a T-test will be done to determine if there is an affect of gender on feelings of Peer Pressure.  Finally, a regression will be done to see if there is an interaction between Gender and Extracurricular Activities on Feelings of Peer Pressure.

attributes.title: CTC - Social Belonging Intervention - University of Waterloo
attributes.description: The CTC’s social-belonging intervention is a multi-site, randomized-controlled trial at 22 U.S. universities and one Canadian university. It uses a between-subjects design with three experimental conditions (control, standard belonging, customized belonging) to test an online activity that seeks to equip students with the most adaptive mindset with which to approach the challenges of the transition into postsecondary education.   University of Waterloo was the only Canadian university to partner in the CTC’s social-belonging intervention, and the only university to have a special focus on STEM (i.e. Science, Technology, Engineering, and Mathematics) programs. University of Waterloo students were invited to participate in 2015, 2016, and 2017.

q1.value: College Transition Collaborative - Social Belonging Intervention - University of Waterloo

q2.value: Konstantyn Sharpinskyi, Christopher Lok, Christine Logel

q3.value:
Some cultural stereotypes allege that math ability is stronger in men than in women, and women are underrepresented in some STEM programs, raising the likelihood that women may have belonging concerns in STEM programs, but not programs outside of STEM. A previous social-belonging intervention conducted at University of Waterloo found that women did underperform academically relative to men, at least those who were in male-dominated STEM majors, and that a social-belonging intervention erased this gap (Walton, Logel, et al., 2015). 

However, that study found underperformance, and treatment effects, only in majors in which women made up fewer than 20% of students. Data on  the gender-diversity of women’s particular major within their STEM program was unavailable at this stage of the project. We were uncertain of whether we would be able to detect effects of the belonging intervention without being able to consider students’ majors, and the proportion of women in them.

The goal of this project was to understand and improve student outcomes at University of Waterloo by developing a tool in the form of an online reading and writing activity, to promote adaptive belonging mindsets, designing a platform on which it could be implemented, and testing its effectiveness. The secondary purpose was to advance psychological theory by investigating for whom, and in which contexts, belonging interventions are effective and what effects, beyond academic outcomes, they may have.

q4.value:
Notes

•	All the analyses will be conducted separately by STEM department: Math, Engineering and Physics.  The programs differ meaningfully in their cultures, student body, and course of study. The treatment was adapted from previous materials designed for engineering students (Walton, Logel, et al., 2015) and then was customized to refer to math- and physics-related issues. Consistent with the idea that these should be treated like three separate interventions, basic, preliminary analyses conducted on the first two cohorts of data for a report to the university staff, done before preregistering, found a different pattern of results across programs.  

•	We did do any tests for program drop out because of the way STEM programs are structured at University of Waterloo: Degree-completion rates are over 80% for mathematics and engineering (data are not easily available for physics) and the programs have course paths to keep students who fail classes in their first year in the program, hence the test would be underpowered.

•	Excitement measure was added as a distractor to orient students away from the seeming negativity of the previous questions. We did not have any hypotheses about it.

•	Close Friends Combined (Follow up) – Average of the mean of Close Friends (Follow up) and average of Friends – How Close for each friend (Follow up) after standardization.

•	Academic Behaviours (Follow up) – Mean of academic behaviours (Follow up).

•	Extracurricular Sum (Follow up) – Sum of the 3 extracurricular activities – How Involved items. 

•	Academic Integration Index (Follow up) – was computed by first standardizing and then averaging the following variables: mean of Close Friends Combined (Follow up), Mentorship (Follow up), Academic Integration (Follow up).  

•	Subjective Wellbeing Index – (Follow up) – the average of Life Satisfaction (Follow up) and Short flourishing (Follow up) after standardization. 

•	All hypotheses will be tested only for students in majors were females represent < 20% of the student body. 

•	Exploratory Hypotheses – exploratory hypotheses were run because we thought that other dependent variables could be affected by the intervention but based on the literature we are unsure as reported results are conflicted.

Main Hypotheses:

1.	Belonging Expectations (Initial) – We expect higher belonging expectation scores for females in the affirmation condition compared to the control. 

2.	Belonging (Follow up) - We expect higher belonging scores in the intervention (vs. control) for females.

3.	Belonging Uncertainty (Follow up) – We expect lower belonging uncertainty in the intervention (vs. control) condition for females.

4.	STEM GPA (Follow up)  – We expect higher STEM GPA in the intervention (vs. control) for females.  We are not including high school GPA as a covariate because there is little overall variance in high school GPA for this sample (everyone is a high performer) and a large international student sub-sample (high school transcript grades are not easily comparable).

5.	Academic Integration Index (Follow up) – We expect higher Academic Integration Index scores for females in the intervention condition (vs. control). 

6.	Loneliness (Follow up) - We expect lower loneliness scores in the intervention (vs. control) condition for females.

Exploratory Hypotheses.

1.	Academic Potential (Follow up) - We expect higher self reported academic potential for females in the intervention (vs. control).

2.	Academic Behaviours (Follow up) – We expect a higher frequency of adaptive academic behaviours in the intervention (vs. control) condition for females. 

3.	Close Friends Combined (Follow up) - We expect greater endorsement of having made close friends in the intervention (vs. control) condition for females.

4.	Extracurricular Sum (Follow up) - We expect greater extracurricular involvement in the intervention (vs. control) condition for females.

5.	Mentorship (Follow up) - We expect a higher frequency of having developed a relationship with a mentor in the intervention (vs. control) condition for females.  

6.	Stress Experience (Follow up) - We expect to see no main effects or interactions here: males and females are expected to experience similar amounts of stress regardless of condition they were assigned to or representation. (In subsequent analyses, we may investigate the degree to which the intervention changes the relationship between stress and belonging. 

7.	Stress Coping (Follow up) - We expect greater stress coping in the intervention (vs. control) condition for females.  

8.	Self – Efficacy (Follow up) – We expect greater self-efficacy for females in the intervention (vs. control) condition for females.

9.	Stereotype Threat (Follow up) – We expect reduced stereotype-threat for females in the intervention (vs. control) condition.

10.	Predicted Retention (Follow up) – We expect higher predicted retention for females in the intervention (vs. control) condition.

11.	Subjective Wellbeing Index (Follow up) – We expect higher subjective wellbeing scores for females in the intervention (vs. control) condition. 

12.	Physical Health (Follow up) – We expect to see improved physical health for females in the intervention condition (vs. control), controlling for physical health at the beginning of the year (when they started university). 

13.	Mental Health Composite (Follow up) - We expect to see improved mental health for females in the intervention condition (vs. control), controlling for mental health at the beginning of the year (when they started university).  

14.	Perceived Transition Difficulty (Initial) - We expect to see the same levels of perceived transition difficulty for males and females, regardless of the intervention.

15.	Professors Fair and Caring (Follow up) - We expect females in the intervention condition to perceive professors as more fair and caring vs. control.

q11.value:
The pre-registration and the analyses will be run by an independent data analyst unaffiliated with the research team.  Other than getting acquainted with the data cleaning process the analyst was not allowed to run any analyses before a draft pre-registration was approved.

A previous data analyst conducted preliminary, basic analyses on the first two cohorts only of data for a report to the participating school. The full dataset has not been analyzed and these particular analyses have not been run.

question.value: Students completed the intervention in the form of an online, text-based activity. At Waterloo, students were invited to participate in the intervention via email. All first-year students at Waterloo were invited to participate in 2015, 2016, and 2017. The intervention was presented to students the summer before they arrived at Waterloo. In follow-up years, some engineering students completed the intervention as part of a first-year course. In the spring of their first year, a subsample of students in each cohort who participated in the intervention completed an online follow-up survey assessing psychological and behavioural outcomes relevant to the intervention.

q13.value: The final sample size is about 8000 people within 3 cohorts for years: 2015, 2016, 2017.

q14.value: All incoming students at the University of Waterloo for 2015, 2016 and 2017 were invited to participate. We aimed to get as many students as possible.

q15.value: A data analyst ran basic, preliminary analyses on the first two cohorts. In part because this determined that statistical power was limited, a third cohort was collected the following year. Collection was stopped after three cohorts because funding and research support was completed.

question.value: Engineering Students were assigned to one of two conditions: control or belonging intervention. Materials for students in the Engineering faculty are attached below. Physics and Math manipulations were exactly the same, just the faculty name was changed accordingly.
See attached document – Measured Variables.

All non-single items scales will be reverse-coded where appropriate and then averaged together. 

The following indices will be computed as follows:

Belonging Expectations variable will be computed by subtracting Belonging Expectations at Time 1 from Belonging Expectations at Time 2.

Mental Health Composite – Mean of z scores of Mental Health (Follow up) and Anxiety and Depression Scanner. 

Close Friends Combined (Follow up) – Average of the mean of Close Friends (Follow up) and average of Friends – How Close for each friend (Follow up) after standardization.

Academic Integration Index (Follow up) – was computed by first standardizing and then averaging the following variables: mean of Close Friends Combined (Follow up), Mentorship (Follow up), Academic Integration (Follow up).  

Subjective Wellbeing Index – (Follow up) – the average of Life Satisfaction (Follow up) and Short flourishing (Follow up) after standardization. 

STEM GPA – raw GPA for STEM courses only for the first academic year – Fall & Winter terms.

1.	Belonging Expectations (Initial) - We will fit a 2-way general linear model in a 2 (gender: male vs. female) x 2 (condition: intervention vs. control) design in female underrepresented majors. For females, expect greater belonging expectations between the intervention and control conditions.

2.	Belonging (Follow up) - We will fit a 2-way general linear model in a 2 (gender: male vs. female) x 2 (condition: intervention vs. control). For Females, we expect a significant difference between the intervention and control condition (higher belonging in the intervention).

3.	Belonging Uncertainty (Follow up) - We will fit a 2-way general linear model in a 2 (gender: male vs. female) x 2 (condition: intervention vs. control) design. For Females, we expect a significant difference between the intervention and control conditions (lower belonging uncertainty in the intervention).

4.	STEM GPA (Follow up) - We will fit a 2-way general linear model in a 2 (gender: male vs. female) x 2 (condition: intervention vs. control) design. For Females, we expect a significant difference between the intervention and control conditions (higher STEM GPA in the intervention condition). 

5.	Academic Integration Index (Follow up) - We will fit a 2-way general linear model in a 2 (gender: male vs. female) x 2 (condition: intervention vs. control) design. For Females, we expect a significant difference between the intervention and control conditions (higher academic integration in the intervention).

6.	Loneliness (Follow up) - We will fit a 2-way general linear model in a 2 (gender: male vs. female) x 2 (condition: intervention vs. control) design. We expect a significant difference between the intervention and control condition (lower loneliness in the intervention).

q20.value: All the dependent variables will be checked for normality and if violated will be transformed using Rankit transformation.

q21.value: For all hypotheses testing, the cut-off will be set to p < 0.05.

q22.value:
Every continuous dependent variable will be checked for outliers and observations outside of 3 standard deviations will be changed to the 3 standard deviation values. 

Participants meeting the following criteria will be excluded:

1. Incomplete responses: We will remove students who did not reach the manipulation.

2. Distraction: We will remove students who indicated that they were "extremely" or "very distracted" throughout the manipulation.

3. Blank or nonsense essay responses (2015 cohort only): We will remove students who did not write anything or wrote nonsense for the main manipulation. 

4. Auto - clicking: We will remove students with little variation in the scale item responses - SD was < 1 for their MC answers.

5. Manipulation Check - We will exclude participants who did not answer the manipulation check correctly.

6. Too little time - We will remove participants who took > 10 minutes to complete the survey.

registration_responses.q1: College Transition Collaborative - Social Belonging Intervention - University of Waterloo
registration_responses.q2: Konstantyn Sharpinskyi, Christopher Lok, Christine Logel
registration_responses.q3:
Some cultural stereotypes allege that math ability is stronger in men than in women, and women are underrepresented in some STEM programs, raising the likelihood that women may have belonging concerns in STEM programs, but not programs outside of STEM. A previous social-belonging intervention conducted at University of Waterloo found that women did underperform academically relative to men, at least those who were in male-dominated STEM majors, and that a social-belonging intervention erased this gap (Walton, Logel, et al., 2015). 

However, that study found underperformance, and treatment effects, only in majors in which women made up fewer than 20% of students. Data on  the gender-diversity of women’s particular major within their STEM program was unavailable at this stage of the project. We were uncertain of whether we would be able to detect effects of the belonging intervention without being able to consider students’ majors, and the proportion of women in them.

The goal of this project was to understand and improve student outcomes at University of Waterloo by developing a tool in the form of an online reading and writing activity, to promote adaptive belonging mindsets, designing a platform on which it could be implemented, and testing its effectiveness. The secondary purpose was to advance psychological theory by investigating for whom, and in which contexts, belonging interventions are effective and what effects, beyond academic outcomes, they may have.
registration_responses.q4:
Notes

•	All the analyses will be conducted separately by STEM department: Math, Engineering and Physics.  The programs differ meaningfully in their cultures, student body, and course of study. The treatment was adapted from previous materials designed for engineering students (Walton, Logel, et al., 2015) and then was customized to refer to math- and physics-related issues. Consistent with the idea that these should be treated like three separate interventions, basic, preliminary analyses conducted on the first two cohorts of data for a report to the university staff, done before preregistering, found a different pattern of results across programs.  

•	We did do any tests for program drop out because of the way STEM programs are structured at University of Waterloo: Degree-completion rates are over 80% for mathematics and engineering (data are not easily available for physics) and the programs have course paths to keep students who fail classes in their first year in the program, hence the test would be underpowered.

•	Excitement measure was added as a distractor to orient students away from the seeming negativity of the previous questions. We did not have any hypotheses about it.

•	Close Friends Combined (Follow up) – Average of the mean of Close Friends (Follow up) and average of Friends – How Close for each friend (Follow up) after standardization.

•	Academic Behaviours (Follow up) – Mean of academic behaviours (Follow up).

•	Extracurricular Sum (Follow up) – Sum of the 3 extracurricular activities – How Involved items. 

•	Academic Integration Index (Follow up) – was computed by first standardizing and then averaging the following variables: mean of Close Friends Combined (Follow up), Mentorship (Follow up), Academic Integration (Follow up).  

•	Subjective Wellbeing Index – (Follow up) – the average of Life Satisfaction (Follow up) and Short flourishing (Follow up) after standardization. 

•	All hypotheses will be tested only for students in majors were females represent < 20% of the student body. 

•	Exploratory Hypotheses – exploratory hypotheses were run because we thought that other dependent variables could be affected by the intervention but based on the literature we are unsure as reported results are conflicted.

Main Hypotheses:

1.	Belonging Expectations (Initial) – We expect higher belonging expectation scores for females in the affirmation condition compared to the control. 

2.	Belonging (Follow up) - We expect higher belonging scores in the intervention (vs. control) for females.

3.	Belonging Uncertainty (Follow up) – We expect lower belonging uncertainty in the intervention (vs. control) condition for females.

4.	STEM GPA (Follow up)  – We expect higher STEM GPA in the intervention (vs. control) for females.  We are not including high school GPA as a covariate because there is little overall variance in high school GPA for this sample (everyone is a high performer) and a large international student sub-sample (high school transcript grades are not easily comparable).

5.	Academic Integration Index (Follow up) – We expect higher Academic Integration Index scores for females in the intervention condition (vs. control). 

6.	Loneliness (Follow up) - We expect lower loneliness scores in the intervention (vs. control) condition for females.

Exploratory Hypotheses.

1.	Academic Potential (Follow up) - We expect higher self reported academic potential for females in the intervention (vs. control).

2.	Academic Behaviours (Follow up) – We expect a higher frequency of adaptive academic behaviours in the intervention (vs. control) condition for females. 

3.	Close Friends Combined (Follow up) - We expect greater endorsement of having made close friends in the intervention (vs. control) condition for females.

4.	Extracurricular Sum (Follow up) - We expect greater extracurricular involvement in the intervention (vs. control) condition for females.

5.	Mentorship (Follow up) - We expect a higher frequency of having developed a relationship with a mentor in the intervention (vs. control) condition for females.  

6.	Stress Experience (Follow up) - We expect to see no main effects or interactions here: males and females are expected to experience similar amounts of stress regardless of condition they were assigned to or representation. (In subsequent analyses, we may investigate the degree to which the intervention changes the relationship between stress and belonging. 

7.	Stress Coping (Follow up) - We expect greater stress coping in the intervention (vs. control) condition for females.  

8.	Self – Efficacy (Follow up) – We expect greater self-efficacy for females in the intervention (vs. control) condition for females.

9.	Stereotype Threat (Follow up) – We expect reduced stereotype-threat for females in the intervention (vs. control) condition.

10.	Predicted Retention (Follow up) – We expect higher predicted retention for females in the intervention (vs. control) condition.

11.	Subjective Wellbeing Index (Follow up) – We expect higher subjective wellbeing scores for females in the intervention (vs. control) condition. 

12.	Physical Health (Follow up) – We expect to see improved physical health for females in the intervention condition (vs. control), controlling for physical health at the beginning of the year (when they started university). 

13.	Mental Health Composite (Follow up) - We expect to see improved mental health for females in the intervention condition (vs. control), controlling for mental health at the beginning of the year (when they started university).  

14.	Perceived Transition Difficulty (Initial) - We expect to see the same levels of perceived transition difficulty for males and females, regardless of the intervention.

15.	Professors Fair and Caring (Follow up) - We expect females in the intervention condition to perceive professors as more fair and caring vs. control.

•	Subjective Wellbeing Index – (Follow up) – the average of Life Satisfaction (Follow up) and Short flourishing (Follow up) after standardization. 

•	All hypotheses will be tested only for students in majors were females represent < 20% of the student body. 

•	Exploratory Hypotheses – exploratory hypotheses were run because we thought that other dependent variables could be affected by the intervention but based on the literature we are unsure as reported results are conflicted.

Main Hypotheses:

1.	Belonging Expectations (Initial) – We expect higher belonging expectation scores for females in the affirmation condition compared to the control. 

2.	Belonging (Follow up) - We expect higher belonging scores in the intervention (vs. control) for females.

3.	Belonging Uncertainty (Follow up) – We expect lower belonging uncertainty in the intervention (vs. control) condition for females.

4.	STEM GPA (Follow up)  – We expect higher STEM GPA in the intervention (vs. control) for females.  We are not including high school GPA as a covariate because there is little overall variance in high school GPA for this sample (everyone is a high performer) and a large international student sub-sample (high school transcript grades are not easily comparable).

5.	Academic Integration Index (Follow up) – We expect higher Academic Integration Index scores for females in the intervention condition (vs. control). 

6.	Loneliness (Follow up) - We expect lower loneliness scores in the intervention (vs. control) condition for females.

Exploratory Hypotheses.

1.	Academic Potential (Follow up) - We expect higher self reported academic potential for females in the intervention (vs. control).

2.	Academic Behaviours (Follow up) – We expect a higher frequency of adaptive academic behaviours in the intervention (vs. control) condition for females. 

3.	Close Friends Combined (Follow up) - We expect greater endorsement of having made close friends in the intervention (vs. control) condition for females.

4.	Extracurricular Sum (Follow up) - We expect greater extracurricular involvement in the intervention (vs. control) condition for females.

5.	Mentorship (Follow up) - We expect a higher frequency of having developed a relationship with a mentor in the intervention (vs. control) condition for females.  

6.	Stress Experience (Follow up) - We expect to see no main effects or interactions here: males and females are expected to experience similar amounts of stress regardless of condition they were assigned to or representation. (In subsequent analyses, we may investigate the degree to which the intervention changes the relationship between stress and belonging. 

7.	Stress Coping (Follow up) - We expect greater stress coping in the intervention (vs. control) condition for females.  

8.	Self – Efficacy (Follow up) – We expect greater self-efficacy for females in the intervention (vs. control) condition for females.

9.	Stereotype Threat (Follow up) – We expect reduced stereotype-threat for females in the intervention (vs. control) condition.

10.	Predicted Retention (Follow up) – We expect higher predicted retention for females in the intervention (vs. control) condition.

11.	Subjective Wellbeing Index (Follow up) – We expect higher subjective wellbeing scores for females in the intervention (vs. control) condition. 

12.	Physical Health (Follow up) – We expect to see improved physical health for females in the intervention condition (vs. control), controlling for physical health at the beginning of the year (when they started university). 

13.	Mental Health Composite (Follow up) - We expect to see improved mental health for females in the intervention condition (vs. control), controlling for mental health at the beginning of the year (when they started university).  

14.	Perceived Transition Difficulty (Initial) - We expect to see the same levels of perceived transition difficulty for males and females, regardless of the intervention.

15.	Professors Fair and Caring (Follow up) - We expect females in the intervention condition to perceive professors as more fair and caring vs. control.

question.value: Students completed the intervention in the form of an online, text-based activity. At Waterloo, students were invited to participate in the intervention via email. All first-year students at Waterloo were invited to participate in 2015, 2016, and 2017. The intervention was presented to students the summer before they arrived at Waterloo. In follow-up years, some engineering students completed the intervention as part of a first-year course. In the spring of their first year, a subsample of students in each cohort who participated in the intervention completed an online follow-up survey assessing psychological and behavioural outcomes relevant to the intervention.

question.value: Engineering Students were assigned to one of two conditions: control or belonging intervention. Materials for students in the Engineering faculty are attached below. Physics and Math manipulations were exactly the same, just the faculty name was changed accordingly.
See attached document – Measured Variables.

All non-single items scales will be reverse-coded where appropriate and then averaged together. 

The following indices will be computed as follows:

Belonging Expectations variable will be computed by subtracting Belonging Expectations at Time 1 from Belonging Expectations at Time 2.

Mental Health Composite – Mean of z scores of Mental Health (Follow up) and Anxiety and Depression Scanner. 

Close Friends Combined (Follow up) – Average of the mean of Close Friends (Follow up) and average of Friends – How Close for each friend (Follow up) after standardization.

Academic Integration Index (Follow up) – was computed by first standardizing and then averaging the following variables: mean of Close Friends Combined (Follow up), Mentorship (Follow up), Academic Integration (Follow up).  

Subjective Wellbeing Index – (Follow up) – the average of Life Satisfaction (Follow up) and Short flourishing (Follow up) after standardization. 

STEM GPA – raw GPA for STEM courses only for the first academic year – Fall & Winter terms.

1.	Belonging Expectations (Initial) - We will fit a 2-way general linear model in a 2 (gender: male vs. female) x 2 (condition: intervention vs. control) design in female underrepresented majors. For females, expect greater belonging expectations between the intervention and control conditions.

2.	Belonging (Follow up) - We will fit a 2-way general linear model in a 2 (gender: male vs. female) x 2 (condition: intervention vs. control). For Females, we expect a significant difference between the intervention and control condition (higher belonging in the intervention).

3.	Belonging Uncertainty (Follow up) - We will fit a 2-way general linear model in a 2 (gender: male vs. female) x 2 (condition: intervention vs. control) design. For Females, we expect a significant difference between the intervention and control conditions (lower belonging uncertainty in the intervention).

4.	STEM GPA (Follow up) - We will fit a 2-way general linear model in a 2 (gender: male vs. female) x 2 (condition: intervention vs. control) design. For Females, we expect a significant difference between the intervention and control conditions (higher STEM GPA in the intervention condition). 

5.	Academic Integration Index (Follow up) - We will fit a 2-way general linear model in a 2 (gender: male vs. female) x 2 (condition: intervention vs. control) design. For Females, we expect a significant difference between the intervention and control conditions (higher academic integration in the intervention).

6.	Loneliness (Follow up) - We will fit a 2-way general linear model in a 2 (gender: male vs. female) x 2 (condition: intervention vs. control) design. We expect a significant difference between the intervention and control condition (lower loneliness in the intervention).

q20.value: All the dependent variables will be checked for normality and if violated will be transformed using Rankit transformation.

q21.value: For all hypotheses testing, the cut-off will be set to p < 0.05.

q22.value:
Every continuous dependent variable will be checked for outliers and observations outside of 3 standard deviations will be changed to the 3 standard deviation values. 

Participants meeting the following criteria will be excluded:

1. Incomplete responses: We will remove students who did not reach the manipulation.

2. Distraction: We will remove students who indicated that they were "extremely" or "very distracted" throughout the manipulation.

3. Blank or nonsense essay responses (2015 cohort only): We will remove students who did not write anything or wrote nonsense for the main manipulation. 

4. Auto - clicking: We will remove students with little variation in the scale item responses - SD was < 1 for their MC answers.

5. Manipulation Check - We will exclude participants who did not answer the manipulation check correctly.

6. Too little time - We will remove participants who took > 10 minutes to complete the survey.

For females, we expect a significant difference between the intervention and control condition (better physical health in the intervention).

For females we expect a significant difference between the intervention and control condition (better mental health in the intervention).

We do not expect any differences either between or within gender. Males and females are expected to perceive transition to university equally challenging.

For females we expect a significant difference between the intervention and control condition (professors perceived as fairer and more caring in the intervention).

registration_responses.q1: College Transition Collaborative - Social Belonging Intervention - University of Waterloo
registration_responses.q3:
Some cultural stereotypes allege that math ability is stronger in men than in women, and women are underrepresented in some STEM programs, raising the likelihood that women may have belonging concerns in STEM programs, but not programs outside of STEM. A previous social-belonging intervention conducted at University of Waterloo found that women did underperform academically relative to men, at least those who were in male-dominated STEM majors, and that a social-belonging intervention erased this gap (Walton, Logel, et al., 2015). 

However, that study found underperformance, and treatment effects, only in majors in which women made up fewer than 20% of students. Data on  the gender-diversity of women’s particular major within their STEM program was unavailable at this stage of the project. We were uncertain of whether we would be able to detect effects of the belonging intervention without being able to consider students’ majors, and the proportion of women in them.

The goal of this project was to understand and improve student outcomes at University of Waterloo by developing a tool in the form of an online reading and writing activity, to promote adaptive belonging mindsets, designing a platform on which it could be implemented, and testing its effectiveness. The secondary purpose was to advance psychological theory by investigating for whom, and in which contexts, belonging interventions are effective and what effects, beyond academic outcomes, they may have.
registration_responses.q4:
Notes

•	All the analyses will be conducted separately by STEM department: Math, Engineering and Physics.  The programs differ meaningfully in their cultures, student body, and course of study. The treatment was adapted from previous materials designed for engineering students (Walton, Logel, et al., 2015) and then was customized to refer to math- and physics-related issues. Consistent with the idea that these should be treated like three separate interventions, basic, preliminary analyses conducted on the first two cohorts of data for a report to the university staff, done before preregistering, found a different pattern of results across programs.

attributes.title: False Memory for Auditory Category Exemplars Across the Lifespan
attributes.withdrawal_justification: Error made in the hypotheses of the initial registration

attributes.title: Perceptions of Public Opinion Change
attributes.withdrawal_justification: The coronavirus outbreak became national news before we launched this study, so we decided to drop our secondary measure. This measure would have asked about national importance of the items, which has a very different context in the current moment. This decision was made before any data was collected.

attributes.title: Brady et al. Moral Contagion and Political Identity

data.value: No, no data have been collected for this study yet.

name.value: Social inference component of social identity moral contagion project

sample.value: Based on an a priori power analysis using G*power 3.1, we estimate the N required to achieve 95% power based on a small interaction effect size (effect size f = .1) which yielded ~220 participants. Assuming 5-10% dropout due to pre-screening failure (see above), we will collect an additional 20 for a total of 240 participants.

analyses.value: We will perform a 2x2 repeated measures ANOVA analysis

dependent.value:
Perceived political identity strength of each message sender, measured on 1 (not at all identified) to 7 (very identified) Likert scale

hypothesis.value:
We hypothesize that participants will perceive a person who sends political messages using moral-emotional language as more strongly identified with their political group than a person who sends a political message using neutral language.

We hypothesize that participants will perceive people who send moral-emotional messages as less open-minded than people who send neutral-messages (main effect), and that this effect will be largest when a message is sent by the political outgroup (interaction).

We hypothesize that participants will be less interested in having a political discussion with someone who send moral-emotional messages compared to neutral message (main effect), and that this effect will be stronger for outgroup members (interaction).

attributes.title: The tDCS effect on visual working memory over DLPFC and PPC
attributes.description:
Working memory (WM) is a cognitive system that provides access to temporarily maintained information for further processing (Miyake & Shah, 1999). Visual WM (VWM) refers to maintaining and directing the visual information needed for higher cognitive processing in the present moment (Luck & Vogel, 2013). WM performance is a mixture of the quantitative number of objects that can be held in WM (capacity) and the qualitative resolution of the representations of these objects (precision). 

Non-invasive brain stimulation techniques such as transcranial direct current stimulation (tDCS) have gained growing research interest as a promising intervention tool to enhance WM performance  (Andrews et al., 2011; Birba et al., 2017; Brunoni & Vanderhasselt, 2014; Bystad et al., 2016; Fregni et al., 2005; Hoon Ohn et al., 2008; Molaee-Ardekani et al., 2013; Nikolin et al., 2017). TDCS delivers weak current from anode to cathode through the skull, generating electric fields to modulate cortical activities and facilitate neuroplasticity (Ruffini et al., 2013; Roche et al., 2015). 

More recently, inconsistent tDCS effects on WM performance have been reported. Some research has found that WM capacity can be improved by tDCS over the dorsolateral prefrontal cortex (DLPFC) and/or posterior parietal cortex (PPC; Andrews et al., 2011; Arciniega et al., 2018; Fregni et al., 2005; Li et al., 2017). Likewise, one study by Heinen et al. (2016) showed that PPC stimulation can potentially enhance WM precision. However, other authors found no effects on WM performance by tDCS over either or both brain regions (Brunoni & Vanderhasselt, 2014; Friedrich et al., 2019; Horvath et al., 2015; Robison et al., 2017). These contrary findings suggest further investigation in tDCS effects on both WM capacity and precision, comparing the stimulations between DLPFC and PPC. 

Wang et al. (2019) recently reported a particularly intriguing finding. They tested the effects of 15-minute anodal tDCS over the left DLPFC and the right PPC relative to a sham condition for 20 participants in a within-subject design. VWM capacity and precision were measured with a continuous reproduction task. In this task, participants memorised the orientations of 2, 4, or 6 bars on a screen. Participants were then asked to reproduce the orientation of one of the bars by mouse-click. The deviation of the reproduced orientation from the original orientation was then used to estimate VWM capacity and precision for each participant, set size, and stimulation condition. Wang et al. observed a selective increase in VWM capacity at set size 6 after PPC relative to sham stimulation, but not after DLPFC stimulation, any other set size, or on VWM precision. 

The potential of brief tDCS to enhance VWM capacity renders it important to test the replicability of this finding. In addition, several aspects of Wang et al.’s (2019) study are potentially problematic and warrant addressing. First, the small sample size translates into low statistical power even for moderate effect sizes, and low statistical power can lead to false-positive findings (Button et al., 2013). The reported effect size is very large (d = 1.028), but this may reflect an overestimate (cf. Halsey et al., 2015). Second, Wang et al. (2019) administered only 60 trials per design cell, which may have led to unreliable estimates of VWM capacity and precision. Third, Wang et al. (2019) failed to assign an equal number of participants to every possible counterbalanced sequence. Therefore, carryover effects across sessions (e.g., practice) have not been adequately controlled in the given VWM tasks. Finally, because Wang et al. (2019) used rotated bars as stimuli, the unique angles of their stimuli effectively ranged only from 0° to 180°, leaving room for developing task-specific strategies. Some, but not all, participants may have realized they could simply memorize the location of just one end of the bar rather than the actual orientation of the bar, thereby making the task considerably easier. This could be problematic in particular in combination with the incomplete counterbalancing and the small number of participants.

In this preregistered experiment, we will conceptually replicate Wang et al.’s (2019) study and address the potential issues of their study by using a bigger sample size, larger number of trials, complete counterbalancing, and stimuli that use the full space of possible angles (360°).

q2.value: Shuangke Jiang, Myles Jones, Claudia C. von Bastian

q4.value:
Two main hypotheses will be tested based on the study results in the original study :
1. PPC stimulation will increase VWM capacity more than DLPFC stimulation. This effect is particularly pronounced at a high difficulty level of the task (i.e., set size 6).
2. Neither PPC nor DLPFC stimulation will improve VWM precision.

q5.value: Experiment - A researcher randomly assigns treatments to study subjects, this includes field or lab experiments. This is also known as an intervention experiment and includes randomized controlled trials.

value: For studies that involve human subjects, they will not know the treatment group to which they have been assigned.

question.value: This is a within-subject design, in which VWM will be repeatedly measured at all set sizes (2, 4 and 6)  over three sessions. Each session will be one of the three stimulation conditions (active DLPFC stimulation, active PPC stimulation and sham stimulation). For the sham condition, half of the participants will receive the sham stimulation over PPC and the other half will receive it over DLPFC. The sequence of all conditions will be counterbalanced (see Randomization).

q9.value:
The same number of participants is expected to be quasi-randomly allocated to each of the 12 combinations (see below). 


      session1                session2               session3
1    Sham (DLPFC)        PPC                        DLPFC
2    Sham (DLPFC)       DLPFC                     PPC
3    PPC                         Sham (DLPFC)       DLPFC
4    PPC                         DLPFC                     Sham (DLPFC)
5    DLPFC                     Sham (DLPFC)       PPC
6    DLPFC                     PPC                         Sham (DLPFC)
7    Sham (PPC)            PPC                         DLPFC

10  PPC                          DLPFC                     Sham (PPC)

q10.value: Registration prior to creation of data

q11.value:
Data (N = 9) have been collected in a pilot study that was reported in a Master’s thesis at the University of Sheffield (Mari, 2019). 

The pilot study served to test the feasibility of the study. No severe adverse effects of the applied tDCS setup have been reported during or after the stimulation. This demonstrates the safety of the experimental design. The same tDCS setup will thus be used in the current study. Equally important, the pilot data were subjected to analysis to develop a feasible analytical workflow (see analysis plan below).

The pilot data indicated no evidence of tDCS effects on neither VWM capacity nor precision. Nevertheless, given the small sample size, results were inconclusive (i.e., ambiguous Bayes factors). The data from the pilot study will be discarded and not used for the current study.

question.value:
Participants will be recruited through online university systems (online research participants system in the Department of Psychology and the University’s volunteer list), social media (e.g., Facebook, Twitter), display of flyers throughout the department, and word-of-mouth. Participants will be compensated with an average of £5 per session (£4 for the first session, £5 for the second session, and £6 for the third session). Psychology undergraduate students will receive course credits for the first two sessions and £5 for the third session. 

Participants are included in the study if they meet the following criteria:
1. Age between 18 and 35 years old.
2. Proficient English for understanding the task instructions.
3. Educated to A-level or higher.
4. Right-handed.
5. No current diagnosis of neurological, psychological or psychiatric illness. 
6. Normal or corrected-to-normal vision, including no colour blindness. 
7. No neurostimulation within the past week.
8. No current medication with known side effects on cognition, in particular memory and attention. 
9. No current recreational drug use (e.g., cannabis, cocaine, or methamphetamines). 

Participants who sign up for the study will be invited to three lab sessions. Each session is expected to last for about 60 minutes and will take place in the Department of Psychology building in Sheffield. Upon their first arrival, participants will receive an information sheet and a consent form. Demographic data including age and gender, native language and educational level will also be collected.  In addition, participants will be asked to confirm their eligibility for the study based on the above criteria.  

We aim to start the study once ethical approval has been obtained, with data collection being completed by 31/05/2020. However, if we do not meet the target sample size, data collection may be completed at a later point at least until the target sample size has been reached.

q13.value: The target sample size is N = 48.

q14.value:
To determine the study sample size, the findings of the original study (Wang et al., 2019)  and the counterbalancing of conditions have been taken into consideration.

Wang et al. (2019) reported a large effect size of Cohen’s d = 1.028, yielding a (post-hoc) power of .984 for their sample of 20 participants in their study. However, simulations have shown that effect sizes are often overestimated (Halsey et al., 2015). Therefore, we decided to base our sample size on a more conservative medium effect size (Cohen’s d = 0.5). Following Halsey et al., (2015), we aim at a power of 1 - β = 0.9. For an α-level of .05 , the minimal sample size is estimated to be 44 (G*power 3.1; Faul et al., 2007).

Counterbalancing the stimulation conditions (i.e., DLPFC, PPC and PPC/DLPFC sham) across three sessions results in 12 possible combinations. Therefore, the sample size needs to be a multiple of 12 (e.g., 24, 36 or 48). Together with the result of the a priori power analysis, we decided for a sample size of N = 48.

q15.value: The data collection will be stopped once the sample size reaches 48.

question.value: We will manipulate set size (2, 4, or 6 memoranda) and stimulation (DLPFC, PPC, or sham stimulation on either DLPFC or PPC).

The dependent variables will be VWM capacity and precision derived from performance in continuous reproduction tasks. 

Participants will be recruited to attend 3 sessions for different stimulation conditions (active DLPFC, active PPC and sham). Each session will last up to 1 hour (3 hours in total) with an interval of at least 48 hours to allow any possible after effects of tDCS to return to baseline ( ‘wash out’). In each one of the sessions, participants will receive stimulation (15 min at 2 mA, 35 cm2) on the DLPFC, stimulation on the PPC, or a sham stimulation on either DLPFC or PPC. In the sham stimulation, tDCS is turned off after ~30 seconds, producing the expected typical ‘tingling’ sensation on the scalp and, thus, providing an effective control condition to minimise placebo effects. The order of three sessions will be counterbalanced across participants. 

After the stimulation, VWM capacity and precision will be measured using continuous orientation reproduction tasks. Each trial begins with a fixation cross displayed centrally for 1000 ms. Next, two, four or six randomly orientated (0-360°) isosceles triangles are arranged in a circular manner and appear on the screen for 200 ms, followed by a 1000 ms blank screen. Note that we will not manipulate the blank interval duration as Wang et al. (2019) did, as they did not observe an effect of tDCS in their short-interval (100 ms, labelled sensory memory) condition. Next, one of the displayed triangles is randomly selected as the target stimulus and presented in a random orientation. Participants are instructed to reproduce the original orientation using the mouse. The reaction time and the recall error (i.e., the difference in degrees between the reproduced orientation and the original orientation) will be measured. The recall error will be used to estimate capacity and precision (see Statistical Models). 

Once participants completed practice trials at set size 2 (50 practice trials in Session 1, and 10 practice trials in Sessions 2 and 3), 360 trials at set size 2, 4 and 6 (120 per set size, intermixed) will be administered to measure post-tDCS VWM performance. The VWM task will be executed with Tatool Web (www.tatool-web.com, von Bastian, Locher, & Ruflin, 2013).
See Statistical Models.

First, recall error will be calculated as the absolute angular difference (from 0 to 180 degrees) between reproduced orientation and presented orientation for each trial. For each stimulation condition and set size separately, VWM capacity and precision will be estimated by fitting the Standard Mixture Model (SMM; Zhang and Luck, 2008) and Swap Mixture Model (SWM; Bays and Husain, 2008) at the recall error distribution using MATLAB 2019a and the MemToolbox (Suchow & Brady, 2013). The fit of the two models will be compared by both the Akaike Information Criterion (AIC) and the Bayesian Information Criterion (BIC). In case the AIC and BIC provide different conclusions, we will use the model favoured by the BIC. 

The SMM is characterised by a mixture of a circular von Mises distribution and a uniform distribution. Specifically, the distribution of recall errors is a weighted summation of two components. The first component is the height of uniform distribution (g), representing random guess responses. This can be used to calculate the probability of the remembered target stimulus (the proportion of the von Mises distribution; Pm = 1-g).  Capacity (K) is the product of Pm and the set size (K = Pm*N).

The second component is the width of Pm, which can be presented by the circular standard deviation (SD) of the von Mises distribution. A smaller SD is interpreted as better precision of VWM. The precision is denoted by the inverse of the SD (SD^-1). 

Calculated parameters (i.e., capacity K and precision SD^-1) in the sham condition will be subtracted from that in active PPC and DLPFC conditions for each set size. These normalised values (∆k and ∆SD^-1) will be used for testing the hypotheses. 

Hypothesis 1 (PPC stimulation will increase VWM capacity, especially at set size 6): 
We will first run an omnibus ANOVA with two within-subjects factors stimulated region (DLPFC/PPC) and set size (2, 4, 6), and the capacity estimates relative to sham (∆k) as the dependent variable. If the interaction is significant, we will follow it up by separate one-way ANOVAs to determine the source of the interaction. Bonferroni-corrected pairwise t-tests and simple-effect analysis will be used to follow up any main effects in the omnibus and the one-way ANOVAs. To replicate Wang et al.'s (2019) analysis, we will further run Bonferroni-corrected paired t-tests against zeros for each region of stimulation and set size, resulting in 6 tests at a corrected alpha-level of .0083. Effect sizes will be estimated with partial eta squared or ANOVA and Cohen's d for t-tests. In addition, Bayes factors will be calculated to indicate the strength of evidence for the absence or presence of effects. 

Hypothesis 2 (neither PPC nor DLPFC stimulation will improve VWM precision): Analyses will be analogous to those for testing Hypothesis 1, with the only difference that the dependent variable will be the precision estimates (∆SD^-1).

q21.value: P value <.05 criteria will be used to interpret significant effects of main effects and interactions. Bayes factors (BFs) between 3 or ⅓ will be interpreted as ambiguous evidence, BFs between 3 and 10 or between ⅓ and 1/10 as moderate evidence, BFs bigger than 10 or smaller than 1/10 as strong evidence in favour of H1 or H0, respectively.

q22.value: Participants who do not fulfill the inclusion criteria (see above) and fail to complete all three sessions will be excluded. In addition, data will be screened to detect participants that did not follow instructions. Specifically, we will exclude participants whose average reaction times in any of the 3 sessions are M ≤ 250 ms.

q23.value: Complete case analysis will be employed. We will listwise delete all data for participants that have one or more missing values.

Working memory (WM) is a cognitive system that provides access to temporarily maintained information for further processing (Miyake & Shah, 1999). Visual WM (VWM) refers to maintaining and directing the visual information needed for higher cognitive processing in the present moment (Luck & Vogel, 2013). WM performance is a mixture of the quantitative number of objects that can be held in WM (capacity) and the qualitative resolution of the representations of these objects (precision). 

Non-invasive brain stimulation techniques such as transcranial direct current stimulation (tDCS) have gained growing research interest as a promising intervention tool to enhance WM performance  (Andrews et al., 2011; Birba et al., 2017; Brunoni & Vanderhasselt, 2014; Bystad et al., 2016; Fregni et al., 2005; Hoon Ohn et al., 2008; Molaee-Ardekani et al., 2013; Nikolin et al., 2017). TDCS delivers weak current from anode to cathode through the skull, generating electric fields to modulate cortical activities and facilitate neuroplasticity (Ruffini et al., 2013; Roche et al., 2015). 

More recently, inconsistent tDCS effects on WM performance have been reported. Some research has found that WM capacity can be improved by tDCS over the dorsolateral prefrontal cortex (DLPFC) and/or posterior parietal cortex (PPC; Andrews et al., 2011; Arciniega et al., 2018; Fregni et al., 2005; Li et al., 2017). Likewise, one study by Heinen et al. (2016) showed that PPC stimulation can potentially enhance WM precision. However, other authors found no effects on WM performance by tDCS over either or both brain regions (Brunoni & Vanderhasselt, 2014; Friedrich et al., 2019; Horvath et al., 2015; Robison et al., 2017). These contrary findings suggest further investigation in tDCS effects on both WM capacity and precision, comparing the stimulations between DLPFC and PPC. 

Wang et al. (2019) recently reported a particularly intriguing finding. They tested the effects of 15-minute anodal tDCS over the left DLPFC and the right PPC relative to a sham condition for 20 participants in a within-subject design. VWM capacity and precision were measured with a continuous reproduction task. In this task, participants memorised the orientations of 2, 4, or 6 bars on a screen. Participants were then asked to reproduce the orientation of one of the bars by mouse-click. The deviation of the reproduced orientation from the original orientation was then used to estimate VWM capacity and precision for each participant, set size, and stimulation condition. Wang et al. observed a selective increase in VWM capacity at set size 6 after PPC relative to sham stimulation, but not after DLPFC stimulation, any other set size, or on VWM precision. 

The potential of brief tDCS to enhance VWM capacity renders it important to test the replicability of this finding. In addition, several aspects of Wang et al.’s (2019) study are potentially problematic and warrant addressing. First, the small sample size translates into low statistical power even for moderate effect sizes, and low statistical power can lead to false-positive findings (Button et al., 2013). The reported effect size is very large (d = 1.028), but this may reflect an overestimate (cf. Halsey et al., 2015). Second, Wang et al. (2019) administered only 60 trials per design cell, which may have led to unreliable estimates of VWM capacity and precision. Third, Wang et al. (2019) failed to assign an equal number of participants to every possible counterbalanced sequence. Therefore, carryover effects across sessions (e.g., practice) have not been adequately controlled in the given VWM tasks. Finally, because Wang et al. (2019) used rotated bars as stimuli, the unique angles of their stimuli effectively ranged only from 0° to 180°, leaving room for developing task-specific strategies. Some, but not all, participants may have realized they could simply memorize the location of just one end of the bar rather than the actual orientation of the bar, thereby making the task considerably easier. This could be problematic in particular in combination with the incomplete counterbalancing and the small number of participants.

In this preregistered experiment, we will conceptually replicate Wang et al.’s (2019) study and address the potential issues of their study by using a bigger sample size, larger number of trials, complete counterbalancing, and stimuli that use the full space of possible angles (360°).
registration_responses.q4:
Two main hypotheses will be tested based on the study results in the original study :
1. PPC stimulation will increase VWM capacity more than DLPFC stimulation. This effect is particularly pronounced at a high difficulty level of the task (i.e., set size 6).
2. Neither PPC nor DLPFC stimulation will improve VWM precision.

registration_responses.q10: Registration prior to creation of data
registration_responses.q11:
Data (N = 9) have been collected in a pilot study that was reported in a Master’s thesis at the University of Sheffield (Mari, 2019). 

The pilot study served to test the feasibility of the study. No severe adverse effects of the applied tDCS setup have been reported during or after the stimulation. This demonstrates the safety of the experimental design. The same tDCS setup will thus be used in the current study. Equally important, the pilot data were subjected to analysis to develop a feasible analytical workflow (see analysis plan below).

The pilot data indicated no evidence of tDCS effects on neither VWM capacity nor precision. Nevertheless, given the small sample size, results were inconclusive (i.e., ambiguous Bayes factors). The data from the pilot study will be discarded and not used for the current study.
registration_responses.q13: The target sample size is N = 48.
registration_responses.q14:
To determine the study sample size, the findings of the original study (Wang et al., 2019)  and the counterbalancing of conditions have been taken into consideration.

Wang et al. (2019) reported a large effect size of Cohen’s d = 1.028, yielding a (post-hoc) power of .984 for their sample of 20 participants in their study. However, simulations have shown that effect sizes are often overestimated (Halsey et al., 2015). Therefore, we decided to base our sample size on a more conservative medium effect size (Cohen’s d = 0.5). Following Halsey et al., (2015), we aim at a power of 1 - β = 0.9. For an α-level of .05 , the minimal sample size is estimated to be 44 (G*power 3.1; Faul et al., 2007).

Counterbalancing the stimulation conditions (i.e., DLPFC, PPC and PPC/DLPFC sham) across three sessions results in 12 possible combinations. Therefore, the sample size needs to be a multiple of 12 (e.g., 24, 36 or 48). Together with the result of the a priori power analysis, we decided for a sample size of N = 48.
registration_responses.q15: The data collection will be stopped once the sample size reaches 48.
registration_responses.q21: P value <.05 criteria will be used to interpret significant effects of main effects and interactions. Bayes factors (BFs) between 3 or ⅓ will be interpreted as ambiguous evidence, BFs between 3 and 10 or between ⅓ and 1/10 as moderate evidence, BFs bigger than 10 or smaller than 1/10 as strong evidence in favour of H1 or H0, respectively.
registration_responses.q22: Participants who do not fulfill the inclusion criteria (see above) and fail to complete all three sessions will be excluded. In addition, data will be screened to detect participants that did not follow instructions. Specifically, we will exclude participants whose average reaction times in any of the 3 sessions are M ≤ 250 ms.
registration_responses.q23: Complete case analysis will be employed. We will listwise delete all data for participants that have one or more missing values.
